revision.comment: Importing Wikidata [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Indian mountaineer" ([[Wikipedia:Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Indian mountaineer}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Harbhajan Singh | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1956|09|10}} | birth_place = Punjab, India | death_date = | death_place = | restingplace = | restingplacecoordinates = | othername = | occupation ITBPolice servic in 1980 = Sportsperson | yearsactive = since 1986 | spouse = | domesticpartner = | children = | parents = | influences = | influenced = | website = {{URL||Official web site}} | awards = [[Padma Shri]]
[[President of India|President]]’s Police Medal
[[Indo-Tibetan Border Police|ITBP]] Insignia
Kishan Singh and Nain Singh Award }} '''Harbhajan Singh''' is an Indian mountaineer, known for his successful mountaineering expeditions of [[Mount Everest]], [[Nanda Devi|Mount Nanda Devi]] and many other peaks in the [[Himalayas|Himalayan]] region.{{cite web | url=http://itbpacademy.nic.in/faculty_off1.html | title=ITBP | publisher=ITBP | date=2014 | accessdate=24 November 2014}} The [[Government of India]] honored him in 2011, with the fourth highest civilian award of [[Padma Shri]].{{cite web | url=http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/LST-PDAWD-2013.pdf | title=Padma Shri | publisher=Padma Shri | date=2014 | accessdate=11 November 2014}}{{cite web | url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2008/20080601/spectrum/main4.htm | title= On a prayer and wings of steel | newspaper=The Tribune | location=India | first=Sanjeev | last=Singh Bariana | date=1 June 2008 | accessdate=20 March 2018 }} ==Biography== {{quotebox|align = right|width=21em|''Will-power acts as fuel to the fire of training before any expedition. The toughest part of the training is to gauge the mood of the mountain, particularly in the last phase when the air becomes too thin to breathe. An able mountaineer should know when exactly to terminate his expedition in case of inclement weather,'' says Harbhajan Singh.}} Harbhajan Singh was born in a very small village namely Dholowal of District Hoshiarpur, Punjab, India on 10 September 1956. He is a former sport person who has started taking part in sports since 1970 and won medals in athletics at state level under 18 years category .He remained best athlete of the college when he was doing his graduation from Khalsa college Garhdiwala. When he was doing his post Graduation from Government college Hoshiarpur he start learning judo and being a new game in Punjab he won medals in various state level competitions.He represented Punjab in Judo and won Gold medal in National judo championship held at Indore ( MP)in 1979.In addition to participating in sports he use to take active part in various other activities of the college. He remained NCC cadet and is “C” certificate holder, he was NSS volunteer and took part in various camps for social service activities, he remained editor of college magazine for punjabi section and an active member of student central association of the college . His career began in 1980 when he joined [[Indo-Tibetan Border Police]] as a gazetted officer through a national level competitive exam and is currently the incumbent Inspector General of [[Indo-Tibetan Border Police|ITBP]]. Singh is credited with three Mt. Everest expeditions and his performance remained remarkable for the significant successful attempts. Since then, he has to his credit successful expeditions to Mt.Nanda Devi,{{cite web | url=http://pib.nic.in/feature/feyr2000/fnov2000/f031120001.html | title=Nanda Devi Expedition | publisher=Press Information Bureau | date=2014 | accessdate=24 November 2014}} the third highest peak in India, and many others such as Mount Abhigamin, Mt. Kamet& Mt.Abhigamin, Mount Mana, Mt.Stopanth,Mount Nunkun, Mt.White Needle(twice),Mount Pinnacle, Mount Pyramid, Mt. North Pyramid, Mt. Sphinx, Mt. Panchachuli, Mount Stok Kangri (twice in winters) Mount Kasket and four un-named peaks(03 in Leh-Ladakh and 01 in H.P) He also has led a team of skiers who skied down after climbing Mt. Abhigamin in 2007 and later on ski down from the 3rd camp (Ht.approximately 23000 ft.) of Mount Everest in 2009.{{cite web | url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/new-high-for-itbp-to-try-skiing-down-everest/412403/ | title=Everest Ski down | publisher=Indian Express | date=19 January 2009 | accessdate=24 November 2014}} ==Awards and recognitions== Harbhajan Singh is a recipient of various following Awards and recognitions conferred by the Government of India and Government of Punjab for his spectacular and significant achievements in the field of Mountaineering and adventure sports and outstanding and meaningful performance as an officer of elite ITBPOLICE Force :- a) Padmashri Award in 2011. b) Tenzing Norgay National Adventure Award in 2016. c) Maharaja Ranjit Singh Award (highest sports Award of Punjab) in 2019. d) IMF Nain singh & Kishan singh life time achievement award in 2011. e) President’s Police Medal for Distinguished services in 2011. f) President’s Police medal for Meritorious services in 2005. g) DG ITBPOLICE Insignia & Commendation roll -13 times. Indian Mountaineering Foundation{{cite web | url=http://www.indmount.org/ | title=IMF | publisher=IMF | date=2014 | accessdate=24 November 2014}} has also extended life membership to him for his significant contributions in the field of mountaineering and promoting adventure activities at International and National level . His name also figure in “Limca book of records and quiz competition books prepared for competitive exam” for his matchless and spectacular contribution in the field of mountaineering and promoting adventure activities activities at International and National level.
==See also== {{Div col}} * [[Adventure sports]] * [[Limca Book of World Records]] {{div col end}} {{portal|India}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * {{cite web | url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/photos-news/photos-india/padmaawards2011/Article4-680261.aspx | title=Padma Investiture Ceremony | publisher=Hindustan Times | date=2014 | accessdate=24 November 2014 | url-status=dead | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141202040824/http://www.hindustantimes.com/photos-news/photos-india/padmaawards2011/Article4-680261.aspx | archivedate=2 December 2014 }} * {{cite book | url=https://books.google.ae/books?id=vo08yl7BbScC&pg=PA352&lpg=PA352&dq=Harbhajan+Singh+mountaineering&source=bl&ots=1KnzHR7Llp&sig=AtOeM5pOAbUSvffyZ7IG9bSL6OM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=WvdyVK3WN4_vapjFgKAN&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=The American Alpine Journal | publisher=American Alpine Club | author=H. Adams Carter | year=1997 | pages=354 | isbn=9780930410391}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Singh, Harbhajan}} [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Recipients of the Padma Shri in sports]] [[Category:Indian mountain climbers]] [[Category:Mountain climbers from Punjab, India]]

{{short description|Kickboxer and mixed martial artist}} {{Infobox martial artist | name = Claire Haigh | other_names = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1980|09|16|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Luxembourg]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = {{flagicon|Luxembourg}} [[Luxembourgish people|Luxembourgish]] | height = {{height|ft=5|in=9}} | weight = {{convert|126|lb|kg st|abbr=on}} | weight_class = [[Bantamweight (MMA)|Bantamweight]] ''(MMA)''
[[Lightweight]] ''(Kickboxing)'' | reach = {{convert|70.0|in|cm|abbr=on}} | style = [[Boxing]], [[Muay Thai]] | stance = [[Southpaw]] | fighting_out_of = [[Phuket]], Thailand | team = Tiger Muay Thai | trainer = | rank = | years_active = 2007 - present | box_win = | box_kowin = | box_loss = | box_koloss = | box_draw = | box_nc = | kickbox_win = 18 | kickbox_kowin = | kickbox_loss = 7 | kickbox_koloss = | kickbox_draw = 1 | kickbox_nc = | mma_kowin = 1 | mma_subwin = 2 | mma_decwin = | mma_koloss = | mma_subloss = | mma_decloss = | mma_draw = 1 | mma_nc = | relatives = | university = | school = | url = | boxrec = | sherdog = 52053 | footnotes = | updated = }} '''Claire Haigh''' is a [[Luxembourgish]] female [[kickboxer]] and [[mixed martial artist]].{{cite news|title= Claire wins WORLD TITLE in Thailand by TKO!|publisher= Diesel Gym|date= |url= http://www.dieselgym.co.uk/claire-wins-world-title-in-thailand-by-tko/|accessdate= 2014-11-24|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20141129223424/http://www.dieselgym.co.uk/claire-wins-world-title-in-thailand-by-tko/|archive-date= 2014-11-29|url-status= dead}} She is the former [[World Professional Muaythai Federation|WPMF]] Lightweight and Super Lightweight champion, as well as the WPMF World Pro League Super Lightweight Champion. She is also the former [[World Muaythai Council|WMC]] Lightweight champion. She is a two time [[International Sport Karate Association|ISKA]] Lightweight World title challenger.{{cite news|title= Claire Haigh|publisher= Awakening Fighters|date=|url= http://www.awakeningfighters.com/athletes/claire-haigh/|accessdate=2014-11-24}} ==Martial arts career== Haigh made her kickboxing debut in 2007, against Sheree Halliday, during Woking Fight Night 4. She lost a decison.{{cite web |title=Fight History |url=http://www.shereehalliday.co.uk/sheree-halliday/fight-history/ |website=shereehalliday.co.uk |accessdate=5 June 2020}} In 2009, Haigh was given the opportunity to fight for the [[World Professional Muaythai Federation]] Lightweight title, against [[Chantal Ughi]]. She won by way of TKO.{{cite web |title=Claire Haigh ( Tiger Muay Thai ) beats Chantal Ughi by TKO @ Queens Cup 2009, Bangkok, Thailand |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pl6mY5l-vSE |website=youtube.com |accessdate=5 June 2020}} Haigh fought [[Chantal Ughi]] for the [[World Professional Muaythai Federation]] Super Lightweight title in the same year, winning a decision.{{cite web |title=World Professional MuayThai Federation Female World Super Lightweight Title |url=https://titlehistories.com/kickboxing/wpmf/wpmf-world-wm-sl.html |website=titlehistories.com |accessdate=5 June 2020}} Haigh defended her WPMF title in 2010, when she faced [[Stephanie Ielö Page]], and won a unanimous decision.{{cite web |title=Je veux que les jeunes du Luxembourg connaissent et apprécient le Muaythaï ! |url=https://fr.muaythaitv.be/news/claire-haigh-n2200.html |website=muaythaitv.be |accessdate=5 June 2020}} Claire Haigh next fought Lanzi Estella for the KSFL World title. She would win a unanimous decision.{{cite web |title=Tiger Muay Thai alumni Claire Haigh wins KSFL World Muay Thai Championship with impressive victory over Sandra Pires |url=https://www.tigermuaythai.com/tiger-muay-thai-alumni-claire-haigh-wins-ksfl-world-muay-thai-championship-with-impressive-victory-over-sandra-pires |website=tigermuaythai.com |accessdate=5 June 2020}} During Penzance Fight Night 2010: Fast And Furious, Haigh faced [[Julie Kitchen]] for the IKF World title.{{cite web |title=Tiger Muay Thai veteran fighter Claire Haigh fights in Europe |url=https://www.fightingthai.com/tiger-muay-thai-veteran-fighter-claire-haigh-fights-in-europe |website=fightingthai.com |accessdate=5 June 2020}} She lost a close split decision.{{cite web |title=Julie Kitchen vs. Claire Haigh |url=https://www.tapology.com/fightcenter/bouts/497129-penzance-fight-night-2010-the-queen-of-muay-thai-julie-kitchen-vs-claire-haigh |website=tapology.com |accessdate=5 June 2020}} Haigh's next fight was likewise a title fight. She fought [[Miriam Nakamoto]] for the [[WBC Muaythai]] Lightweight title. Nakamoto won the bout by knockout.{{cite web |title=Miriam Nakamoto Becomes the First American Woman to Win WBC MuayThai World Title |url=https://www.sherdog.com/news/pressreleases/Miriam-Nakamoto-Becomes-the-First-American-Woman-to-Win-WBC-MuayThai-World-Title-26562 |website=sherdog.com |accessdate=5 June 2020}} Claire Haigh would then go on a six fight winning streak before challenging [[Angélique Pitiot]] for the [[International Sport Karate Association|ISKA]] World Lightweight title. During this winning streak, she defended her lightweight title twice, against Kwanta Soonkeeranakornsree{{cite web |title=TMT’s Claire Haigh defends WPMF 135 pound World Muay Thai Championship |url=https://www.tigermuaythai.com/tmts-claire-haigh-defends-wpmf-135-pound-world-muay-thai-championship |website=tigermuaythai.com |accessdate=5 June 2020}}, and against Nilawan Techasuep.{{cite web |title=Team Tiger Muay Thai fighter Claire Haigh successfully defends WPMF World Muay Thai Championship in Bali Indonesia |url=https://www.tigermuaythai.com/team-tiger-muay-thai-fighter-claire-haigh-successfully-defends-wpmf-world-muay-thai-championship-in-bali-indonesia |website=tigermuaythai.com |accessdate=5 June 2020}} Pitiot won by knockout.{{cite web |title=Angélique PITIOT championne du monde ISKA |url=https://muaythaitv.fr/news/angelique-pitiot-championne-du-monde-iska-n2582.html |website=muaythaitv.fr |accessdate=5 June 2020}} She fought and defeated Nong Nan Jor Nguan in 2012 for the [[World Muaythai Council|WMC]] World Lightweight title in 2012.{{cite web |title=World Muaythai Council Female World Lightweight Title |url=https://www.titlehistories.com/kickboxing/wmc/wmc-world-wm-l.html |website=titlehistories.com |accessdate=5 June 2020}} ==Championships and accomplishments== *'''[[World Professional Muaythai Federation]]''' **WPMF World Lightweight Championship (135 lbs) ***Two successful title defenses **WPMF World Super Lightweight Championship (140 lbs) **WPMF World Pro League Super Lightweight Championship (140 lbs) *'''[[World Muaythai Council]]''' **WMC World Lightweight Championship (135 lbs) ==Kickboxing record== {| class="toccolours" style="width:100%; clear:both; margin:1.5em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! colspan="2" style="background:darkGrey;"| Kickboxing/Muay Thai Record (incomplete) |- valign="top" |
'''18 Wins, 7 Loss, 2 Draws'''

{{short description|Italian footballer}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Accursio Bentivegna | fullname = Accursio Bentivegna | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1996|06|21|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Sciacca]], Italy | height = {{height|m=1.70}} | position ={{ubl|[[Forward (association football)|Winger]]|[[Second striker]]}} | currentclub = | clubnumber = | youthyears1 = 2010–2015 | youthclubs1 = [[U.S. Città di Palermo|Palermo]] | years1 = 2014–2018 | clubs1 = [[U.S. Città di Palermo|Palermo]] | caps1 = 7 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2015 | clubs2 = → [[Calcio Como|Como]] (loan) | caps2 = 15 | goals2 = 1 | years3 = 2017 | clubs3 = → [[Ascoli Picchio F.C. 1898|Ascoli]] (loan) | caps3 = 11 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2017–2018 | clubs4 = → [[Carrarese Calcio|Carrarese]] (loan) | caps4 = 31 | goals4 = 5 | years5 = 2018–2020 | clubs5 = [[Carrarese Calcio|Carrarese]] | caps5 = 28 | goals5 = 1 | nationalyears1 = 2013 | nationalteam1 = [[Italy national under-17 football team|Italy U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2014 | nationalteam2 = [[Italy national under-18 football team|Italy U18]] | nationalcaps2 = 4 | nationalgoals2 = 6 | nationalyears3 = 2014–2015 | nationalteam3 = [[Italy national under-19 football team|Italy U19]] | nationalcaps3 = 5 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2015 | nationalteam4 = [[Italy national under-20 football team|Italy U20]] | nationalcaps4 = 2 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | club-update = 22 February 2020 | nationalteam-update = 7 January 2015 }} '''Accursio Bentivegna''' (born 21 June 1996) is an Italian [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]].
==Club career== Born in [[Sciacca]], [[Province of Agrigento]], [[Sicily]], Bentivegna started his career at [[U.S. Città di Palermo|Palermo]], playing for their primavera side. He made his [[Serie A]] debut for Palermo against [[U.C. Sampdoria|Sampdoria]] as a substitute replacing [[Franco Vázquez]]. On 31 August 2014, he moved to Como on loan. He scored his first goal for Como on 27 October 2015, in a 3−1 defeat against [[A.C. Cesena|Cesena]].
After scarcely playing for Palermo's first team, he was loaned out to Serie B club [[Ascoli Picchio F.C. 1898|Ascoli]] in January 2017.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

{{chinese name|Wang}} {{Infobox Politician | honorific-prefix = | native_name = 王克敏 | native_name_lang = zh | name = Wang Kemin
| image = Wang Kemin.jpg | imagesize = | office = Chairman of the [[Provisional Government of the Republic of China (1937–1940)|Provisional Government of the Republic of China]] | term_start = 14 December 1937 | term_end = 30 March 1940 | predecessor = ''Position Established'' | successor = ''Position Abolished'' | office2 = Chairman of the North China Political Council | term_start2 = 30 March 1940 | term_end2 = 5 June 1940 | predecessor2 = ''Position Established'' | successor2 = [[Wang Yitang]] | term_start3 = 2 July 1943 | term_end3 = 8 February 1945 | predecessor3 = [[Zhu Shen]] | successor3 = [[Wang Yintai]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1879|05|04|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Hangzhou]], [[Zhejiang]] Province, [[Qing dynasty|Empire of China]] | death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|1945|12|25|1879|05|04}} | death_place = [[Beijing]], [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]] | nationality = | spouse = | party = | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = | profession = | religion = | signature = | footnotes = }} '''Wang Kemin''' ({{zh|t=王克敏|s=王克敏|p= Wáng Kèmǐn }}; [[Wade-Giles]]: Wang K'o-min, May 4, 1879 – December 25, 1945) was a leading official in the Chinese republican movement and early [[Beiyang]] government, later noted for his role as in the [[collaborationist]] [[Provisional Government of the Republic of China (1937–1940)|Provisional Government of the Republic of China]] and [[Wang Jingwei regime]] during World War II. == Biography == [[File:Wang Kemin2.jpg|thumb|Wang Kemin during the [[Beiyang government]]|200px]] Wang was a native of [[Hangzhou]] in [[Zhejiang]] province. In 1901, he was dispatched by the government of [[Qing Dynasty]] China to [[Japan]], where he studied western economics and accounting from his nominal position as attaché at the Chinese embassy in [[Tokyo]]. After his return to China in 1907, he was appointed to a post under the [[Viceroy of Zhili]] to manage foreign affairs. After the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]] had been established, he was sent to [[France]] in 1913. On his return, by orders of [[Duan Qirui]] he helped establish the [[Bank of China]], and became its president from July 1917. He served as minister of finance under the [[Beiyang Government]] from December 1917 to March 1918. In December 1918, he was the only representative of the Beiyang Government to attend a meeting with the Nanjing Government in an attempt to reunify China. He served as Minister of Finance again from July–August 1923 under the premiership of [[Gao Lingwei]]. However, Wang was strongly opposed by the [[Fengtian clique]] led by [[Zhang Zuolin]], and forced to resign his post after only a week. He returned as Minister of Finance with the support of [[Cao Kun]] of the [[Zhili clique]] from November 1923-October 1924. During this time, he also oversaw the operations of a number of other banks, including the [[National Industrial Bank of China|Bank of Tianjin]]. After the success of [[Chiang Kai-shek]]'s [[Northern Expedition (1926–1927)|Northern Expedition]] a warrant for Wang's arrest was issued by the [[Kuomintang]] and he fled to [[Dalian]] in the [[Kwantung Leased Territory]] under Japanese jurisdiction. In 1931, Wang Kemin returned to Beijing when [[Zhang Xueliang]] took control of [[Hebei]] Province, and took a post in the Peking Finance committee. He became mayor of Tianjin in 1932. In 1935 Wang was in the [[Kuomintang]] Hebei Government and had a post in the Northeast Government Affairs Committee, and the Peking Government Affairs Committee and other important posts. However, he retired to Shanghai in 1935. After the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]] broke out in 1937, the [[Imperial Japanese Army]] quickly overran [[North China]], and the Japanese [[Imperial General Headquarters]] authorized the creation of a collaborationist regime as part of its overall strategy to establish an autonomous buffer zone between China and Japanese-controlled [[Manchukuo]]. This government was based in Beijing, and proclaimed Wang Kemin accepted the post of President of the [[Provisional Government of the Republic of China (1937–1940)|Provisional Government of the Republic of China]], with its capital in Beijing on December 14, 1937. The government nominally controlled the provinces of [[Hebei]], [[Shandong]], [[Shanxi]], [[Henan]] and [[Jiangsu]]. But its activities were carefully prescribed and overseen by advisors provided by the [[Japanese Northern China Area Army]]. The failure of the Japanese to give any real authority to the Provisional Government discredited it in the eyes of the local inhabitants, and made its existence of only limited propaganda utility to the Japanese authorities.Black, ''World War Two: A Military History'', page 34 The Provisional Government was, along with the [[Reformed Government of the Republic of China]], merged into [[Wang Jingwei]]'s [[Wang Jingwei regime|Nanjing Nationalist Government]] on March 30, 1940, but in practical terms actually remained virtually independent under the name of the "[[North China Political Council]]" ({{lang|zh-Hant|華北政務委員會}}) until the end of the war. Wang Kemin retained power as Chairman of the North China Political Council, as well as becoming Internal Affairs Minister in the Nanjing Nationalist Government. Wang was arrested by the government of the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]] after the [[surrender of Japan]] and tried for [[treason]]. He committed suicide before the conclusion of his trial on December 25, 1945. == References == {{reflist}} == Bibliography == * David P. Barrett and Larry N. Shyu, eds.; ''Chinese Collaboration with Japan, 1932-1945: The Limits of Accommodation'' Stanford University Press 2001 * John H. Boyle, ''China and Japan at War, 1937–1945: The Politics of Collaboration'' (Harvard University Press, 1972). * James C. Hsiung and Steven I. Levine, eds., ''China's Bitter Victory: The War with Japan, 1937–1945'' (Armonk, N.Y.: M. E. Sharpe, 1992) * Ch'i Hsi-sheng, ''Nationalist China at War: Military Defeats and Political Collapse, 1937–1945'' (Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press, 1982). * Frederick W. Mote, ''Japanese-Sponsored Governments in China, 1937–1945'' (Stanford University Press, 1954). * Howard L Boorman and Richard C. Howard, eds.; ''Biographical Dictionary of Republican China, Volume I: AI - CH'U'', Columbia University Press, 1967. == External links == * [http://baike.baidu.com/view/452091.htm 王克敏_百度百科] biography with photo * [http://info.datang.net/W%5CW0247.htm 王克敏] biography {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wang, Kemin}} [[Category:1879 births]] [[Category:1945 deaths]] [[Category:Republic of China politicians from Zhejiang]] [[Category:Chinese collaborators with Imperial Japan]] [[Category:World War II political leaders]] [[Category:Chinese politicians who committed suicide]] [[Category:Prisoners who died in Chinese detention]] [[Category:People who committed suicide in prison custody]] [[Category:Politicians from Hangzhou]] [[Category:Qing dynasty politicians from Zhejiang]] [[Category:Republic of China people born during Qing]]
